;;周六（10 月 14 日），数千名巴勒斯坦人逃离加沙地带北部，躲避以色列预计的地面袭击路线，而以色列则对该地区进行了更多空袭，并表示保持两条道路开放，以便人们逃离。本报告由吉莉安·基奇纳 (Jillian Kitchener) 制作。这份报告包含图形内容。;
;

;以色列军方周日表示，在其部队预计对加沙地带发动地面攻击之前，将继续允许加沙人撤离南部，以报复前所未有的袭击八天前由哈马斯武装分子袭击。

;

;军方表示，以色列对飞地进行了有史以来最猛烈的轰炸，造成以色列境内 1,300 人死亡，其中包括 279 人，数十万人已经向南迁移。以色列士兵。

;

;加沙当局表示，迄今为止已有 2,300 多人死亡，其中四分之一是儿童，近 10,000 人受伤。飞地的医院医疗用品短缺，难以应对不断涌入的伤者。

;

;其中有四岁的;Fulla Al-Laham;，包括父母和兄弟姐妹在内的 14 名家庭成员死亡在以色列空袭中。

;

;“愿上帝让我活着来照顾她，”她的祖母乌姆·穆罕默德·拉哈姆 (Um Muhammed Al-Laham) 说道，当她躺在医院里，小女孩缠着绷带时，她握着她的手。手臂上打点滴。

;

;巴勒斯坦卫生部周日早些时候表示，过去 24 小时内加沙已造成 300 人死亡、800 多人受伤。

;

;作为以色列人在地面行动之前，空袭仍在继续，一些加沙人表示，他们已决定返回北部家园，因为那里都不安全。

;

;以色列发誓要消灭哈马斯;武装分子于 10 月 7 日在以色列城镇横冲直撞，向男人、女人和儿童开枪，并在最严重的情况下劫持人质该国历史上针对平民的袭击。

;

;有关袭击的生动视频片段以及医疗和紧急服务部门对被占领的城镇和基布兹暴行的报告加深了以色列的震惊感。

;

;以色列军方周五告诉加沙地带北半部的居民（其中包括加沙城超过一百万居民）立即向南迁移。

;

;在国际社会呼吁保护平民的背景下，以色列军方加强了应对措施以色列军方周日表示，将继续允许加沙人向南部撤离。

;

;“加沙城的居民们，我再次呼吁你们：哈马斯正试图阻止你们撤离。我们将使其向南移动。为了您的人身安全，请离开加沙城和所有周边地区。”以色列首席军事发言人丹尼尔·哈加里少将在电视简报中说。

;

;哈马斯已告诉加沙人不要遵守以色列的撤离命令。

;

;一些南下的巴勒斯坦人说，他们正在向北返回，因为无论他们走到哪里，都会受到来自天空的攻击。<​​/p>;

;“这有什么意义？他们在加沙城、努赛尔特（加沙地带中部）、汗尤尼斯和拉法进行轰炸，”加沙会计师阿布·达乌德说。

;

;“我要把我的家人带回来。进入加沙。我不能继续住在学校或家外面，反正没有地方是安全的，我的家更好，”他说。

;

;胡萨姆·阿布·萨菲亚 (Hussam Abu Safiya)，儿童病房的重症监护医生加沙地带北部卡迈勒·埃德万医院的一名医生表示，不可能下达撤离的命令。

;

;“正如你所见，在这个病房里，有一些需要呼吸机的儿童，现在我们被要求要疏散医院，我们应该将这些儿童疏散到哪里？”他说。

;

;哈马斯表示，周五对载有难民的汽车和卡车的袭击造成数十人死亡。路透社无法独立核实这一说法.

;

;一些加沙人发誓要留下来，因为他们记得“Nakba”或“灾难”，当时许多巴勒斯坦人在以色列建国的 1948 年战争期间被迫离开家园。

;

;美国国务卿 ;安东尼·布林肯; 正在该地区寻求确保释放以色列所说的被哈马斯带回加沙的 126 名人质，并防止战争蔓延。

;

;布林肯表示，他举行了一次“非常富有成效”的会议周日在利雅得与沙特王储穆罕默德·本·萨勒曼会面，原定稍后前往埃及，埃及的拉法过境点现在被视为援助到达加沙的主要门户。他将于周一再次前往以色列。

;

;萨勒曼表示，沙特阿拉伯正在努力防止冲突升级，并希望帮助解除以色列对加沙的围困。

;

;暴力事件自2006年以来，加沙地带的冲突一直伴随着以色列北部与黎巴嫩边境发生的最致命的冲突，引发了人们对战争蔓延到另一条战线的担忧。

;

;以色列的地区敌人伊朗支持哈马斯，对哈马斯对以色列的袭击表示赞赏但否认有任何参与。其联合国代表团周六晚间表示，如果以色列不立即停止“战争罪行和种族灭绝”，“局势可能会失控”并产生深远的后果。

;

;哈马斯在一份声明中表示，伊朗“;同意继续合作;”以实现该组织的目标。

;

;以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡的国家安全顾问周六警告同样得到伊朗支持的黎巴嫩激进组织真主党，不要采取可能导致黎巴嫩“;毁灭;"。

;

;以色列与以色列边境发生冲突迄今为止受到限制的黎巴嫩于周日恢复，真主党战士 ;向以色列边境村庄发射了一枚导弹;，造成一人死亡、三人受伤。以色列军方表示，他们正在黎巴嫩发动袭击以进行报复。

;

;同样与以色列接壤并与伊朗有联系的叙利亚指责以色列对其机场进行袭击，而以色列则指责伊朗试图通过叙利亚走私武器。

;

;总统乔·拜登的 2024 年连任团队及其政党周日表示，他们在最近一个季度筹集了 7100 万美元，因为这位民主党人的年龄和低支持率仍然是一个问题。

;

;截至 9 月底，民主党连任工作手头有 9100 万美元的现金，涉及多个领域。 80 岁的拜登在决定在 2024 年谋求连任四年任期时，曾克服对自己年龄的质疑，但他正在努力应对民意调查显示的对总统年龄的担忧以及选民热情下降的问题。民主党选民。

;

;拜登的竞选团队总部位于他的家乡特拉华州威尔明顿，该团队表示将利用迄今为止筹集的资金雇用员工、在竞争激烈的州组织起来并开展广告活动。

;<共和党前总统称，竞选团队预计将在未来几周内和年底之前再次大举招聘，开始制定一项行动，以打击高级助手目前认为的 2024 年 11 月 5 日选举中可能的对手唐纳德·特朗普。

;

;相比之下，时任总统特朗普和共和党全国委员会在 2019 年第三季度为连任筹集了 1.25 亿美元。前总统巴拉克·奥巴马 (Barack Obama) 和民主党全国委员会在 2011 年筹集了 7000 万美元，按通胀调整后的计算，拜登的最新数字将落后于拜登。

;

;拜登竞选团队宣布的筹款金额无法与共和党竞争对手直接比较，因为其中包括拜登盟友控制的政党账户。

;

;共和党人尚未选出提名人，并正在将部分竞选资金用于相互对抗。

;

;

;他的竞选活动为富人举办的筹款活动多于为公众举办的政治集会，并表示自发起以来组织了 75 场筹款活动，其中包括本季度 37 日，小额“草根”筹款约占筹集资金总额的三分之一。

;

;

;推动在线草根筹款的一些时刻包括“与总统会面”筹款竞赛，筹集了近 2.5 美元。自 8 月以来，“Dark Brandon”马克杯和随附视频创造了 200 万美元的收入。

;作为以色列;周日;准备对哈马斯控制的加沙地带发动地面攻击，在空袭中失去家人的巴勒斯坦人正在准备迎接更多的破坏。

;

;Um Mohammad Al-Laham 4 岁的孙女 Fulla Al-Laham 躺在加沙的一家医院里，该医院和其他医院一样，药品和燃料供应不足。她说，以色列空袭袭击了芙拉的家，造成 14 人死亡，其中包括芙拉的父母、兄弟姐妹和她的大家庭成员。

;

;“突然间，他们在没有任何警告的情况下，在屋顶上炸毁了房子。多年来，她目睹了哈马斯和以色列军队之间的许多战争。

;

;她说这是最艰难的一次。

;

;

;“十四人殉难，除了芙拉之外，无人幸存，”她说。 “她不说话，什么也不做，只是躺在床上，他们给药。” 祖母说，家里的另一名 4 岁孩子也几乎没有亲人了。 .

;

;以色列对加沙发动了有史以来最猛烈的空袭。

;

;以色列誓言要消灭巴勒斯坦激进组织哈马斯，以报复其武装分子八天前在以色列城镇发动的暴行。武装分子枪杀了男人、女人和儿童，并扣押了人质，这是该国历史上对平民最严重的袭击。

;

;在这场意外的袭击中，约 1,300 人被杀，手机视频画面和来自以色列对拥有 230 万巴勒斯坦人的家园的加沙进行了围困，并要求人们离开飞地北部的家园，向南迁移。

;

;哈马斯敦促人们不要离开，称外出道路不安全。据称，周五载有难民的车辆遭到袭击，造成数十人死亡，而医务人员、哈马斯媒体和亲属则表示，整个家庭在空袭中丧生。

;

;联合国表示，如此多的人无法在加沙境内安全转移而不造成人道主义灾难。

;

;加沙当局表示，已有 2,300 多人死亡，其中四分之一是儿童，近 10,000 人受伤。

;

;救援人员正在搜寻夜间空袭的幸存者.

;

;预期的以色列地面进攻和空袭引发了人们对这个狭窄、贫困的飞地——世界上最拥挤的地方之一——遭受前所未有的苦难的担忧。

;

;在加沙的卡迈勒埃德万医院（Edwan Hospital）的一些儿童使用了呼吸机，胡萨姆·阿布·萨菲亚（Hussam Abu Safiya）医生说：“如果你想杀我们，就在我们继续在这里工作的时候杀掉我们，我们不会离开。我们需要几天甚至几周的时间来确保另一个地方的安全。”

;

;“情况真的很危险，”他说。“将这些孩子从这个地方转移出去就等于给他们判了死刑。他们会死，而这种设备只能依靠电力和氧气来运行。”

;

;医院表示，在以色列的封锁下，他们的药品和燃料已经耗尽。

;

;加沙城的目击者告诉路透社，以色列的攻势迫使更多的人离开家园，一些人在医疗机构寻求庇护。加沙最大的希法医院人满为患。

;

;“我们正在经历一生中最糟糕的噩梦。即使在医院，我们也不安全。黎明时分，医院外地区遭到空袭”，一位不愿透露姓名的 35 岁妇女说道。

;

;由于一些人行程中称，以色列继续在其周围轰炸。无法立即联系到以色列军方发表评论。

;

;President Vladimir Putin said on Sunday that suggestions the United States should prepare for a war against Russia and China were nonsense, and warned the West that any war against Russia would be on a whole different level to the conflict in Ukraine.

;

;A bipartisan panel appointed by the US Congress said on Thursday that Washington ;must prepare; for possible simultaneous wars with Moscow and Beijing by expanding its conventional forces, strengthening alliances and enhancing its nuclear weapons modernization programme.

;

;Putin, who is to ;visit China; this week, said the United States had stoked tensions with Beijing by building the "AUKUS" security alliance of ;US, Australia and Britain; and that Russia and China were not building a military alliance.

;

;Putin told Kremlin reporter Pavel Zarubin in a clip published on Sunday that thoughts of war between Russia and the United States were unhealthy but that if people were making such thoughts public they could not but cause concern to Moscow.

;

;"I don't think these are healthy thoughts in the minds of healthy people, because to say that the United States is preparing for war with Russia, well we are all preparing for war because we follow the ancient principle: if you want peace, get ready for war," Putin said in a clip posted on Telegram.

;

;"But we want peace," Putin said with a chuckle. "Moreover, to fight with both Russia and China, it is nonsense - I don't think it is serious. I think they are just scaring each other."

;

;The deepening partnership between the rising superpower of China and Russia, the world's biggest nuclear power, is one of the most intriguing geopolitical developments of recent years - and one the West is watching with anxiety.

;

;The United States casts China as its biggest competitor and Russia as its biggest nation-state threat while US President Joe Biden argues that this century will be defined by an existential contest with between democracies and autocracies.

;

;Putin cautioned that if the United States fought against Russia then it would be very different to the war in Ukraine that the Kremlin calls a special military operation.

;

;"And if they want to fight with Russia then it will be a completely different war - it will not be carrying out a special military operation," Putin said. "Look at the Middle East - is that a special military operation - can you compare them?"

;

;"If we talk about a war between great nuclear powers, then it would be a completely different story. I don't think that people in their right minds can think about such a thing, but if such a thought does come to them then it can only cause us to be wary."

;

;The United States says that both Russia and China are modernising their nuclear weapons arsenals and that China will likely have a stockpile of ;1,500 nuclear warheads; by 2035 if it continues with its current pace of nuclear buildup.

;

;Putin controls around ;5,889 nuclear warheads; as of 2023, compared with 5,244 controlled by Biden, according to the ;Federation of American Scientists;. Of those, Russia has about 1,674 deployed strategic nuclear warheads while the United States has 1,670.

;;
;;The US Capitol is seen at sunrise as Republican House members will today continue their search to find a House speaker following the ouster of Kevin McCarthy, in Washington, US, October 13, 2023. REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque;
;

;As the flames of war burn in the Middle East and Ukraine, the US Congress is immobilized by a brawl among Republicans, a dysfunction that even some in Donald Trump's party worry is giving comfort to the nation's adversaries.

;

;The House of Representatives has drifted leaderless for 12 days since eight of its 221 Republicans ousted Speaker Kevin McCarthy. That has held up any legislative action, from debating further aid to Ukraine as it battles a Russian invasion to a statement of support for ally Israel in its war with Hamas.

;

;Republicans on Friday ;nominated; hardliner ;Jim Jordan; for speaker, but it was not clear if the longtime antagonist of party leadership would have the support needed to win a floor vote this week.

;

;McCarthy's removal was the latest in a series of self-created crises Congress has faced in a year that saw lawmakers bring the federal government to the brink of defaulting on its $31.4 trillion in debt and just two weeks ago narrowly avert the fourth partial US government shutdown in a decade.

;

;That latter move led to McCarthy's ouster by colleagues angry that the spending bill passed with more Democratic than Republican votes, even though any measure passed by the House needs to clear the Democratic-controlled Senate and be signed by Democratic President Joe Biden to become law.

;

;Some House Republicans voiced frustration and anger that they have gone so long without being able to choose a leader.

;

;"The world is on fire. Our adversaries are watching what we do and ... quite frankly, they like it," said Republican House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Michael McCaul.

;

;Speaking to reporters as his colleagues huddled to discuss their next moves, McCaul added, "I see a lot of threats out there. One of the biggest threats I see is in that room because we can't unify as a conference."

;

;The dysfunction was undermining Americans' already weak confidence in Congress, with two-thirds of respondents to a ;Reuters/Ipsos survey; this month saying they did not believe Washington politicians could set aside partisan differences for the good of the nation. Half said they did not believe lawmakers could carry out their most basic function of passing laws.

;

;Former President Trump, the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican nomination, has at times been a cheerleader for the chaos.

;

;The logjam continued as fighting in the Middle East intensified with Israel launching an assault on the Gaza Strip following a surprise attack by Hamas fighters.

;

;Lawmakers of both parties have voiced support for Israel, but a leaderless House has been unable to take any official action. Republican Representative Zach Nunn said the conflict hit home in his Iowa district.

;

;He said a local family struggled to fly out of Israel until a private airplane was arranged, a Des Moines family was "trapped" in Gaza and some military friends aboard US ships now in the Mediterranean would see their paychecks suspended if Congress does not avert a government shutdown next month.

;

;"Let's start passing budgets. Let's start moving forward with our national security. Let's stand with our strongest ally in the Middle East right now. And most importantly, let's have a government that is functioning," Nunn told reporters.

;

;House Democrats echoed that stance.

;

;"We hope our Republican colleagues will put an end to the self-inflicted chaos so that we can begin to govern on behalf of the American people," Representative Pete Aguilar, a member of House Democratic leadership, told reporters.

;

;The troubles are not confined to the House.

;

;In the Democratic-controlled Senate, a Republican has since February single-handedly held up the confirmations of hundreds of military officers, including many top commanders.

;

;Senator Tommy Tuberville is protesting a Pentagon policy that reimburses service members for out-of-state travel to access abortions.

;

;After the attack on Israel, Tuberville said he will not drop his blockade of Biden's nominees.

;

;Meanwhile, 20 months into Moscow's invasion of Ukraine, many Republicans in Congress want to back away from additional military and economic aid to Kyiv, feeding uncertainty about the US commitment to stand up to Russian President Vladimir Putin.

;

;"With the pressing needs we have right now for additional support for both Israel and Ukraine, the lack of a speaker ... is very problematic," said Elizabeth Hoffman, director of congressional and government affairs at the Center for Strategic & International Studies.

;

;"The needs are very urgent and are not getting less urgent," she said in a telephone interview.

;

;All year Congress has been locked in a bitter struggle as hardline House Republicans demand profound government spending cuts as a way of starting to tame a budget deficit that reached about $1.7 trillion in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30.

;

;As a result, federal agencies face many of their operations ceasing on Nov. 17 unless a deal can be reached.

;

;"I just sense a real clash coming here in early November," said William Hoagland, senior vice president at the Bipartisan Policy Center.

;

;Some Republicans were not fazed by the House's lingering stalemate.

;

;"We can go without a speaker for a long time because Congress doesn't actually have to be in," said Representative Scott Perry, who chairs the right-wing House Freedom Caucus. "The American people are at work today. Babies are being born today and this isn't the first thing on their priority list."
